subject: Re: [junit] Re: Suggestion: New addition to the Assert class
msgSnippet: This is an area where pragmatism wins for me: the extra code isn t much better than just throwing the exception into the framework, so I don t bother. YMMV. So
messageBody:
This is an area where pragmatism wins for me: the extra code isn't much
better than just throwing the exception into the framework, so I don't
bother.

YMMV.

So said martijn_dashorst <yahoogroups@...> on 2/12/2003
--------------------

>> The fail(Throwable) throws a subclass of AssertionFailedError that
>> supports chained exceptions: so that you won't loose one bit of the
>> stacktrace. So please, please no more "fail(e.getMessage())"!
>
>I use this to specifically test for exceptions. If I want to test
>whether my FooFileLoader throws an FileNotFoundException, I do the
>following, instead of letting the framework handle the exception as
>an error. I think it is just a matter of definition of what consists
>of a failure of your requirement (in this case the contract of the
>FooFileLoader) or an error.
>
>testFileNotFound(){
> try{
> FooFileLoader f = new FooFileLoader( "unknownfile.txt" );
> fail( "FileNotFoundException expected, got none" );
> } catch( FileNotFoundException e ){
> // success!
> } catch( Exception e ){
> fail( "FileNotFoundException expected, caught: " + e );
> }
>}
>
>Regards,
>
>Martijn Dashorst
